channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: London Perl and Raku Workshop
item.description: October 26, 2024, in London, UK

item.title: Purdue Perl Mongers
item.description: August 14, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: GitHub Pages for Perl developers
item.description: August 15, 2024, in Zoom

item.title: Boston.pm monthly meeting
item.description: August 13, 2024, Virtual event

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week.

item.title: The Sudden Appearance of Asterisks
item.description: Line by line discussion is very handy even if the language is alien. This week choice of languages for post are Raku and Rust. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #280
item.description: Interesting use of finite state machine with detailed discussion. Loved the use of Unicode character. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 280
item.description: Simple use of hash in Perl is good enough for Twice Appearance task. Smart approach, well done.

item.title: Counting the stars
item.description: Interesting use of regex and we have pretty cool solutions in Perl. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: Appear Twice, Count Once
item.description: I liked the Approach section where we get to see the finer details then implementation in varieties of languages. Highly recommended.

item.title: There Is More Than One Way To Regex
item.description: Love the journey to get the desired output. Plenty to learn from the experience. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 280
item.description: Ideal use case for one-liner in Perl this week by master of one-liners. You really don't want to skip it.

item.title: grepping everything!
item.description: Mix of Raku, Python, Java and PostgreSQL will keep you busy as always every week. Pleasure to see how implementation differs. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 280: Count Asterisks
item.description: Great show of regex in Perl and Raku. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 280: Twice Appearance
item.description: Straight forward and to the point without any gimmicks. Short little discussion is very handy too. Great work.

item.title: Regular Pairs
item.description: Well documented extended regex solutions, very brave indeed. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 280
item.description: Simply use split and hash, you end up with nice easy to follow solution. Smart and clever approach.

item.title: Why Is This Interesting?
item.description: See how to keep the logic simple and still get the elegant solution. Incredible, keep it up great work.

item.title: Count Twice
item.description: Powerful one-liner in Raku is on demand every week. Keep it up great work.

item.title: TWC280
item.description: Time for some clever regex in Perl and you end up with one-line. Cool work, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Asterisks Appear Twice
item.description: Welcome back to blogging. Suprise to see do { } for loop construct. Highly recommended.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 280
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Twice Appearance" and "Count Asterisks" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 281
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Check Color" and "Knight's Move". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Why Perl Remains Indispensable in the Age of Modern Programming Languages
item.description: An honest opinion and view about Perl. What do you think?

item.title: This week in PSC (154)
item.description: Regular updates from Perl Steering Council. Happy to see the progress report. Thank you all for your time and efforts.

item.title: Deploying Dancer Apps (Addendum)
item.description: This is the second post in continuation to what was discussed in earlier post: Deploying Dancer Apps.

item.title: What's new on CPAN - June 2024
item.description: Please checkout the monthly post abput the cool collection of CPAN modules. Find out more about the new addition.

item.title: GitHub Pages for Perl developers (Free Virtual presentation on August 15)
item.description: In this virtual event you will learn how to use Markdown and GitHub Pages to create a simple web site and then we'll extend our use of GitHub Actions to generate the site using Perl. Register now!

item.title: Continuous Integration (CI): GitHub Actions for Perl Projects
item.description: Video recordings

item.title: Perl Advent Calendar 2024 CFP
item.description: You are cordially invited to write an article for the 2024 Perl Advent Calendar. The CFP is open until midnight on Friday September 30th EST.

item.title: #680 - Advent Calendar
item.description:
Hi there,

I know we still have 4 months before the Advent Calendar season kicks in but I noticed the ground work has already started by Olaf Alders with the announcement of The Call for Papers for the 2024 Perl Advent Calendar. The CFP is open until midnight on Friday September 30th EST. I would like to request all Perl fans to share their fun encounter with Perl as an article for the upcoming Perl Advent Calendar 2024. I have already submitted my proposal and keeping my fingers crossed. While talking about, Advent Calendar, I would love to see Dancer2 Advent Calendar to come back with full force. If I remember correctly, we didn't have the complete calendar last year. Being Dancer2 fan, I would really want it to get back to its peak. Dave Cross is one of those who uses Dancer2 for building applications. In the recent post, he shared his experience about deploying Dancer Apps. Even my personal website is a Dancer2 REST API application.

It's a bit late to share but better late than never. We have the monthly post about What's new on CPAN - June 2024 by Mathew Korica. Kudos for the effort and thanks for keeping the tradition alive.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
